trans-unit.source: Configuring and using the Storage Emulator with Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Configuring and using the Storage Emulator with Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Configuring and using the Storage Emulator with Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Configuring and using the Storage Emulator with Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: The Azure SDK development environment includes the storage emulator, a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table storage services available in Azure on your local development machine.
trans-unit.target: The Azure SDK development environment includes the storage emulator, a utility that simulates the Blob, Queue, and Table storage services available in Azure on your local development machine.

trans-unit.source: If you are building a cloud service that employs the Azure storage services, or writing any external application that calls the storage services, you can test your code locally against the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: If you are building a cloud service that employs the Azure storage services, or writing any external application that calls the storage services, you can test your code locally against the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio integrate management of the storage emulator into Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Tools for Microsoft Visual Studio integrate management of the storage emulator into Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Tools initialize the storage emulator database on first use, starts the storage emulator service when you run or debug your code from Visual Studio, and provides read-only access to the storage emulator data via the Azure Storage Explorer.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Tools initialize the storage emulator database on first use, starts the storage emulator service when you run or debug your code from Visual Studio, and provides read-only access to the storage emulator data via the Azure Storage Explorer.

trans-unit.source: For detailed information on the storage emulator, including system requirements and custom configuration instructions, see <linkText>Use the Azure Storage Emulator for Development and Testing</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For detailed information on the storage emulator, including system requirements and custom configuration instructions, see <linkText>Use the Azure Storage Emulator for Development and Testing</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: There are some differences in functionality between the storage emulator simulation and the Azure storage services.
trans-unit.target: There are some differences in functionality between the storage emulator simulation and the Azure storage services.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Differences Between the Storage Emulator and Azure Storage Services</linkText><title></title> in the Azure SDK documentation for information on the specific differences.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Differences Between the Storage Emulator and Azure Storage Services</linkText><title></title> in the Azure SDK documentation for information on the specific differences.

trans-unit.source: To access the storage emulator from code within a role, you will want to configure a connection string that points to the storage emulator and that can later be changed to point to an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: To access the storage emulator from code within a role, you will want to configure a connection string that points to the storage emulator and that can later be changed to point to an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: A connection string is a configuration setting that your role can read at runtime to connect to a storage account.
trans-unit.target: A connection string is a configuration setting that your role can read at runtime to connect to a storage account.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to create connection strings, see <linkText>Configuring the Azure Application</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to create connection strings, see <linkText>Configuring the Azure Application</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can return a reference to the storage emulator account from your code by using the DevelopmentStorageAccount property.
trans-unit.target: You can return a reference to the storage emulator account from your code by using the DevelopmentStorageAccount property.

trans-unit.source: This approach works correctly if you want to access the storage emulator from your code, but if you plan to publish your application to Azure, you will need to create a connection string to access your Azure storage account and modify your code to use that connection string before you publish it.
trans-unit.target: This approach works correctly if you want to access the storage emulator from your code, but if you plan to publish your application to Azure, you will need to create a connection string to access your Azure storage account and modify your code to use that connection string before you publish it.

trans-unit.source: If you are switching between the storage emulator account and an Azure storage account frequently, a connection string will simplify this process.
trans-unit.target: If you are switching between the storage emulator account and an Azure storage account frequently, a connection string will simplify this process.

trans-unit.source: You can specify that when you run or debug your service in Visual Studio, Visual Studio automatically launches the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: You can specify that when you run or debug your service in Visual Studio, Visual Studio automatically launches the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for your Azure project and choose Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the shortcut menu for your Azure project and choose Properties.

trans-unit.source: On the Development tab, in the Start Azure Storage Emulator list, choose True (if it isn't already set to that value).
trans-unit.target: On the Development tab, in the Start Azure Storage Emulator list, choose True (if it isn't already set to that value).

trans-unit.source: The first time you run or debug your service from Visual Studio, the storage emulator launches an initialization process.
trans-unit.target: The first time you run or debug your service from Visual Studio, the storage emulator launches an initialization process.

trans-unit.source: This process reserves local ports for the storage emulator and creates the storage emulator database.
trans-unit.target: This process reserves local ports for the storage emulator and creates the storage emulator database.

trans-unit.source: Once complete, this process does not need to run again unless the storage emulator database is deleted.
trans-unit.target: Once complete, this process does not need to run again unless the storage emulator database is deleted.

trans-unit.source: Starting with the June 2012 release of the Azure Tools, the storage emulator runs, by default, in SQL Express LocalDB.
trans-unit.target: Starting with the June 2012 release of the Azure Tools, the storage emulator runs, by default, in SQL Express LocalDB.

trans-unit.source: In earlier releases of the Azure Tools, the storage emulator runs against a default instance of SQL Express 2005 or 2008, which you must install before you can install the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: In earlier releases of the Azure Tools, the storage emulator runs against a default instance of SQL Express 2005 or 2008, which you must install before you can install the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can also run the storage emulator against a named instance of SQL Express or a named or default instance of Microsoft SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: You can also run the storage emulator against a named instance of SQL Express or a named or default instance of Microsoft SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: If you need to configure the storage emulator to run against an instance other than the default instance, see <linkText>Use the Azure Storage Emulator for Development and Testing</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need to configure the storage emulator to run against an instance other than the default instance, see <linkText>Use the Azure Storage Emulator for Development and Testing</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The storage emulator provides a user interface to view the status of the local storage services and to start, stop, and reset them.
trans-unit.target: The storage emulator provides a user interface to view the status of the local storage services and to start, stop, and reset them.

trans-unit.source: Once the storage emulator service has been started, you can display the user interface or start or stop the service by right-clicking the notification area icon for the Microsoft Azure Emulator in the Windows taskbar.
trans-unit.target: Once the storage emulator service has been started, you can display the user interface or start or stop the service by right-clicking the notification area icon for the Microsoft Azure Emulator in the Windows taskbar.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage node in Server Explorer enables you to view data and change settings for blob and table data in your storage accounts, including the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage node in Server Explorer enables you to view data and change settings for blob and table data in your storage accounts, including the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Browsing and Managing Storage Resources with Server Explorer</linkText><title></title> for more information.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Browsing and Managing Storage Resources with Server Explorer</linkText><title></title> for more information.
